content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								What the hell happened to this game? When I backed the game on Kickstarter years ago, it actually had some interesting gameplay: tile-based strategy, items, multiple characters... That's all gone now. What's left is... a repetitive, unbalanced, and uninspired button-mashing action game.This is the first game that after years of work has actually gotten much less developed than when it started! It's sad. I don't know where they're going, but it doesn't seem like a good place. Maybe they plan to someday add all the interesting features back into the game, but for the moment stay away.

number of helpful: 62 of 89 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kickstarted that game LONG ago, looked promising with some kind of strategy in real time, involving a hero with support troop battling enemies. What we got is a strange action game where you spam buttons, every enemy move in a chaotic way and you have some bullets, but not much strategy involved... In fact, you empty both your guns, you use your grenades, then usually some enemies are still alive. The key then? Melee them going on their square... They'll catch in fire and you can just spam the attack until they die. You either win in 30 seconds or lose in 10-20 seconds. And every mission look the same.It really feels like a game made by 1 or 2 persons in their house in their spare time. I know it's early access, but with a delivery date that was stated for October 2013, it's nowhere near a good game.If they don't do major fixes, don't buy this game, it's not worth it. I've kickstarted other games that did deliver what they promised in general (Massive Chalice, Darkest Dungeon, Battle World Kronos) in time and I think this game is going nowhere.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I am really torn about this game? And here are the reasons why... I saw it about half a year ago. It was supposed to be a downloadable release on xbox 1 maybe 360... anyway, the sprites and enemies were the same however the background has drastically been changed from a lucius HD platform to a pixelated pile of dog doo doo. I understand that this is a early access game or whatever but I purchased it on sale for half price and it still isnt worth any money. Its an unfinished demo, not even, a taste of what the game might be like if it ever comes full circle. Which it prob. wont. Dont miss understand, I really like where the game is going, and I hope it gets finished, but I cant help but feel that some of these smaller game developers are slowly watching their dream slip between their fingers so they throw whatever they can at the community to scrounge whatever money they can out of the "burnt-out" project their shoveling on real fans. Games like Mighty No. 9, CHASM, games I want more then anything to be realized, to become lies and trickery. This game has been around way to long to not be finished by now. God, I hope these ICs prove me wrong, but I'm not gonna hold my breath and you my friend shouldnt waste your money.

number of helpful: 40 of 42 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Early backer here. Backed on Kickstarter based on the pitch in the middle of 2013. Played the alphas, liked where it was going. Seriously, look at the difference:https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1054244612/c-wars-roguelike-pixel-art-pc-game/descriptionTons of radio silence throughout this, of course. There was limited mention about why things were taking so long, what was going on with the team, etc. Eventually I just forgot about it.Then, suddenly, they went to Early Access. Man, was I excited - I thought the alpha must have progressed enough to warrant releasing it on Steam! But... alas... it wasn't the same game pitched at all. It didn't feel the same, the battlefields weren't structured the same way, my dreams of playing this on a touch interface were basically shattered.What happened? Everyone, including the dev, said to give it time. Fair enough. So, after August 20th, 2015, I waited. I figured, well, if things need to be overhauled, that'll take a few months, right? Three? Why stop there? Let's wait 5, just to give it extra time.Man, what a let down. I know it's early access still, but this game's two years past the original deadline. It feels like a flash game, it runs like a flash game. Activating the "grid" to see movement literally puts hex outlines in a checkerboard pattern on a square grid, and the player can only move in the four cardinal directions. The controls for keyboard are rather poor. The best part of the game, the animations, are choppy and have a limited amount of frames each (it's like they were animated on fours rather than twos or ones) and the sprites themselves are low detail. It's hard to get into the game when it's so clunky, but the majority of it seems to be moving from battle to battle with little to do inbetween. The combat itself is tedious to the point that I'd rather just go do chores.I can't recommend this game. I'll probably let it sit in my library until it's out of early access (if that happens), but it's on my "remove from account without refund because it's that bad" list.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								tl;dr version first: this game is a waste of time.The tutorial is ridiculous and has too much in-universe fluff.  I don't mine Rogue-Likes if there's a point to it.  This game is quite pointless, however, as the difficulty in missions make no sense early on.  There's no real way to earn any progress, the store where you're supposed to upgrade your units is broken, and there are far too many glitches to count.  At one point, my character got stuck in the far-right, bottom of the screen and is completely unable to do anything.  Meanwhile, this zombie with a machine gun, dressed up as a police officer, has decimated my entire team.  But there's nothing that I can do except to go back to the Title.  The lack of in-game manual is substituted by hitting the "Tab" key to get some vague explanations about features that you can't even use.

Posted: August 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early days, still plenty of promise. 3 available characters who all have different skills and quests available. Missions basically played like real-time chess, characters move on squares while a bunch of enemies spawn that you take down using abilities, 1-use items and anything else that goes boom. Levels didn't seem to be randomly generated as suggested, not sure if that's a bug or WIP. Gamepad and mouse controls were available but only keyboard worked for me. Asking price is fair given the current content and with everything said, if a fan of tactics, pixel art and anime it's worth at least keeping on your radar.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Opening caveat: I am a kickstarter backer of the game, and received this copy as a result of thatA lot of reviews comment on the fact that you're not getting a lot for your money. There's hardly any content, and it's incredibly buggy. These reviews were posted within the first day or two of release, and do not reflect the current stage of the game right now. This is, after all, an early access game. Oni-punks have been releasing near-daily updates, adding content and tweaking bugs since release. Is this a finished product? Not hardly. But what it IS is a taste of what the final game will entail. You have a grid, you move on the grid, you attack your enemies. Conserve your ammo, choose your targets, and time your attacks properly to avoid reprisal. There are three characters, each with unique weapons and abilities. Each has a set of stages through which they must pass, along with optional side missions. Since that first release, bugs have been fixed, the stages have been improved and organized better, and the game in general just feels better as well. As I said, it's still more of a demo than anything, but it's growing steadily.In time, you will have helper characters, along with a wider variety of heroes and weapons from which to choose. Sure, it's been a long time coming, but it's heartening to see these basic building blocks, to know that the game DOES exist. As long as the flow of updates continues to be as rapid as it has been, I, for one, will continue to recommend this game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								To preface this review, this is based on the Early Access version I was provided from the Kickstarter I had back almost 2 years ago. With that being said, let me be perfectly clear: This is not a game. This is essentially a limited demo with pretty much an hour worth of content. Due to the incredibly unfinished condition of this "game", I cannot recommend it to anyone. When it comes the game itself, what it provides it decent enough. Three separate characters, each with their own missions (although they barely vary) and they all control pretty differently. EDIT 8/20/15: They now have a prompt that shows the control scheme, which alleviates some of the issue of not knowing what's going on.That's not nearly enough to understand what's going on with multiple weapon types, ammo counts to manage different ranges for each and much more. You end up fumbling around until you somehow find the magic attack that is strong against the particular enemy type. Gameplay aside, there is practically nothing left. No story, no customization, very limted sound and music. After waiting two years after plunking down cash on this project, I am horrifically disappointed that this is all they've had to show. I pray they are able to crank out updates on a regular basis to flesh out what is essentially 99% of the remaining content. If they can release an actual game soon and not a paid and shallow demo, then you should look into this. As for now though, stay far away.

number of helpful: 40 of 84 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
This early access release is actually worse than the alpha releases that came out before steam availability. What you currently see, the title screen, 3 barely playable heroes in a few stages with only a couple of finished enemy sprites has been in development since early 2013. This is all a full 2 years+ of dev time shows. Add to it the fact that they had spent 3 years prior to work on the engine itself. Speaking of the engine - "Our self-developed engine ensures better performance. Small reminder: ONI-engine packed 800+ pixel animations into 1Megabyte, about half the size of a photo taken with your phone." That was scrapped, the entire game is now based in unity. Originally the animation and engine looked great the artists had ton tons of sprites and animation of high quality. Late 2014 Oni dissolved it's team. While the Founding dev nsisted it was due to "fame and discipline" the press at chuapp (a Chinese news blog) was able to contact former team members who stated (loosely translated)Originally posted by devteam:"two reasons: Project outlook is bleak and unbearable leader character."Leaving only it's founding developer to direct, program, (possibly animate as well since the sprites have gotten worse) and market the game. The development remained stagnant for months. Currently the founder has hired a minimal team and had this to say about developmentOriginally posted by founder:"Well we don't have the manpower or time or willing to add anything else into the game which is not related to the game itself." (Extra content, proper DRM, etc) "We have barely enough people to finish the game."AVOID AT ALL COSTS. This game is not worth your money. It is not feature rich, it is hardly playable, and it shows no promise of ever getting better.This game has managed to get worse in gameplay/features and animation since original pre-steam release..

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Disclaimer: I'm a kickstarter backer so the low play time count on Steam does not reflect  actual game time since I have been playing the alpha builds released prior to Steam. TLDR Game Description: Are you aware of the megaman exe series before? If you are, this plays a lot like it, if you aren't the units here move in real time along a grid, and you move on the grid to dodge enemy attacks and launch your own attacks. The game mechanics are extremely addicting as it is reflex and tactically based, there are lots of times you can die but you will want to retry it. Yeah so, just a background C-Wars was actually a game pitched in kickstarter more than 2 years ago, the dev team underwent severe issues both personally and financially and as a result the game spent time in development hell and entered early access by the skin of its teeth...this is the reason why the game has a lot of negative reviews when it was first launched it was really closer to a tech demo than an actual game. FORTUNATELY, the dev team went into super saiyan mode and started releasing daily updates since then, right now I can say it can be positively compared to other EA games in terms of actual content, and consequently is now worth the EA price. For the price of a cup of coffee you get beautiful pixel art, ok music and fun and frenetic gameplay. I suggest you buy it now because the price will likely increase. I mean at the end of the day the game is receiving daily updates, patches, bug fixes and various quality of life improvements so it will definitely be worth your purchase. Buy it now and encourage them to improve the game even more. Plus, it is highly original this is the first megaman exe style game I've seen anywhere apart from the original megaman exe games themselves.
